meanings.sent1: I accidentally got a snick on my finger while cutting vegetables.
meanings.sent2: The carpenter made a snick in the wood to mark the measurement.
meanings.sent3: The snick on the tree trunk looked like a tiny smile.
meanings.sent4: Her snick in the paper was so precise, it almost looked like a drawing.
meanings.sent5: The snick on the edge of the coin made it unique among the collection.

meanings.sent1: I heard the door snick shut behind me as I left the room.
meanings.sent2: The old typewriter would snick with each keystroke.
meanings.sent3: The snick of the light switch turning off echoed in the empty room.
meanings.sent4: The lock finally snicked into place, securing the door tightly.
meanings.sent5: The gears in the clock snicked softly as they turned, marking the passage of time.

meanings.definition: To catch or lock with a latch or bolt
meanings.sent1: She managed to snick the bracelet around her wrist before the clasp broke.
meanings.sent2: The gate snicked closed behind the last person to enter the garden.
meanings.sent3: The squirrel tried to snick the nut from the bird feeder but got caught in the process.
meanings.sent4: The puzzle pieces snicked together perfectly, completing the picture.
meanings.sent5: The door snicked shut, sealing off the room from the noisy hallway.
